paragraph: In this phase of the problem lies the third great difference between Jung’s interpretation of the observed phenomena and that of Freud.Jung definitely recognizes that there are many neurotic persons who clearly exhibited in their childhood the same neurotic tendencies that are later exaggerated. Also that an almost overwhelming effect on the destiny of these children is exercised by the influence of the parents, the frequent over-anxiety or tenderness, the lack of sympathy or understanding, in other words, the complexes of the parent reacting upon the child and producing in him love, admiration, fear, distrust, hate, revolt. The greater the sensitiveness and impressionability of the child, the more he will be stamped with the familial environment, and the more he will unconsciously seek to find again in the world of reality the model of his own small world with all the pleasures and satisfactions, or disappointments and unhappinesses with which it was filled.
question: What role does the child's sensitivity and impressionability play in their development of neurotic tendencies?
answer: The child's sensitivity and impressionability play a crucial role in their development of neurotic tendencies. These traits make the child more susceptible to the influences of the familial environment. As a result, the child may unconsciously seek to recreate their small world in the real world, experiencing the same pleasures, satisfactions, disappointments, and unhappinesses that defined their early environment.
